body: I should mention that this file was generated with topojson’s `--allow-empty` flag. If empty features are removed, then the winding problems also go away.

OK, I’ve proposed a fix in #1454. You can see it working here:

[![screen shot 2013-08-12 at 12 39 55 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/949966/0e7bda72-0387-11e3-94aa-f72c5b641ca3.png)](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/3dcaeba25a75304ddafa)

However, this really needs @jasondavies’ review, because I’m not confident that my fix is correct. (And it breaks a few tests, which might be brittle.)

To investigate this, I modified your example to use the equirectangular projection, and it turns out that the degenerate polygon is being interpreted as CCW.  Even though `d3.geo.area` returns exactly zero, note that the projection has a rotation, and if you compute the area of the rotated polygon, it is no longer exactly zero; it is around -8e-22.

One thing I’ve been intending to do is swap the order of rotation and clipping, so that this area calculation would occur prior to rotation.  This means that programs such as TopoJSON can predict exactly which polygons would have this issue; we’d no longer be at the “mercy” of the precision of rotated coordinates.

Initially I was tempted to add an epsilon of -1e-12 for point-in-polygon (which calculates area internally), and d3.geo.area for consistency.  However, the use of degenerate polygons should really be avoided if possible.  Most geometry algorithms simply don’t allow them, and it’s the same for self-intersecting polygons.  So if it’s practical, I’d prefer to have a consistent winding order algorithm (which isn’t dependent on rotation).

If we do end up wanting an epsilon, for whatever reason, note that it could have implications for the clip-polygon branch.  I think 1e-12 is probably okay, but we wouldn’t want anything much bigger in case it clashes with clip polygons that cover most of the globe (which is usually the case).  This is mainly why I’d prefer to stick with zero instead of an epsilon if possible.

One more thing: it’s strange that modifying clipExtent above fixed the issue.  I need to look into that to see what went wrong as that does seem like a bug.

Thanks for investigating. Sorry for not understanding the problem exactly, but your description makes sense.

I like the idea of rotating after clipping. In addition to being more predictable and consistent, that should have better performance, as the cost of a rotating the cut (antimeridian or circle) is likely negligible, and then there will be fewer points to rotate after clipping.

Regarding degenerate polygons, do you think there’s a related improvement we could make in TopoJSON? I don’t really see that there’s much we could do, if we want to retain empty features. There’s a coincident point in the example polygon above, which we could remove, but that wouldn’t fix the immediate problem.

Based on feedback from @jasondavies re. the difficulty of implementation (and the fact that this bug can be avoided by removing empty features from input), we’re moving this bug to the 3.3.x milestone.

Any progress on this, @jasondavies? I received another report of nondeterministic winding order detection when rotation is applied. I’ll try to track down another reproducible test case. I’d really like to make the projection code more robust in this regard. (The need for large polygons is rare, and the number of times small polygons have been misinterpreted is more frequent than I’d like.)
I’m afraid I haven’t had time to work on it recently, sorry!  I should have some time next week.

Seems like this is visible in your [Geographic Clipping](http://www.jasondavies.com/maps/clip/) demonstration as well. If I rotate to [52, 100, 0](also occurred at [17, 100, 0]) I see the following unexpected behavior in the equirectangular projection:

![screen shot 2013-09-13 at 7 48 21 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/1142715/4de70720-1ce8-11e3-9ef2-59a51939d631.png)

issue.title: Fix point-in-polygon for multiple polar rings.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Instead of detecting if any single polygon ring winds around a pole, we
consider the cumulative winding of all polygon rings together.  This is
consistent with the area calculation, which considers the cumulative
area total of all rings.

This fixes #1521: an issue with the Hammer Retroazimuthal projection,
which uses such a polygon with two rings, covering most of the globe.

In addition, drop the special handling of points at the south pole,
which might have been there to pass an incorrect test: a CCW triangle
touching the south pole, which was probably incorrectly thought to be
clockwise.  This fixes an issue with a “stripe” polygon rotated so that
a point is at the south pole, mentioned in #1453.

body:
> One more thing: it’s strange that modifying clipExtent above fixed the issue. I need to look into that to see what went wrong as that does seem like a bug.

Have you had a chance to investigate this part of it yet? Although I suppose if the root issue is the winding order check giving a spurious result due to rotation-induced error then probably introducing a clipExtent introduces a second bug, which happens to cancel the effect of the first bug. :)

issue.title: Fix clipExtent bug.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
If a polygon does not intersect with the extent, but has one or more rings inside the extent, then the extent should be checked to see whether it is inside the polygon: if so, an additional exterior ring is generated.

Previously, this check was only made if there were no visible rings at all.

Fixes an issue noticed in #1453.

body:
> Have you had a chance to investigate this part of it yet?

Yes, you were right.  This was a bug that happened to cancel out the first bug. :)

issue.title: Perform winding order check on unrotated polygons.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
We remove the rotation step that occurred prior to clipping, so that clipping processes unrotated polygons.  Note that clip regions are defined relative to the rotated globe, so clipping now needs a rotation parameter.

Rather than moving the rotation step so it occurs after clipping, the rotation occurs as part of clipping, using the rotation parameter to rotate streamed points.  Alternatively, points could be clipped against a rotated clip region, and then subsequently rotated as a separate step, but this seems slightly less efficient.

Fixes #1453.
